comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Seen at an open house air show somewhere in the eastern USA is Douglas A-4E Skyhawk 152023 Tail code AJ of Carrier Air Wing Eight (CVW-8) Modex 310. ‘USS FORRESTAL’ on rear fuselage This aircraft belonged to VA-83 ‘Rampagers’ during 1965. The US Navy accepted A-4E 152023 Constructor Number 13411 on April 28, 1965. Flew first with US East coast based VA-83 ‘Rampagers’ off CVA-59 USS Forrestal on a Mediterranean patrol during 1965. And so A-4E 152023 went to war in 1967 with VA-106 ‘Gladiators’ of CVW-17 code AA from USS Forrestal. Part of the US Sixth Fleet and Atlantic coast based, USS Forrestal sailed half way round the world for a Vietnam War deployment - via the South Atlantic Ocean, around Southern Africa and the Cape of Good Hope into the Indian Ocean and across to the South China Sea and Gulf of Tonkin. After only five days of operations a cataclysmic event occurred aboard the ship. A-4E 152023 was aboard USS Forrestal on the day of the July 29 1967 accidental and catastrophic flight deck explosions and consequential horrific fire above and below decks with the tragic loss of 134 servicemen’s lives and severe injury to another 62 while ‘on the line’ in the Gulf of Tonkin off North Vietnam. There was also true heroism displayed on that fateful day. Plus twenty one expensive aircraft were lost in the devastating incident. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1967_USS_Forrestal_fire www.va106vf62.org/gladiator_website_006.htm www.navy.mil/navydata/nav_legacy.asp?id=73 a4skyhawk.org/content/forrestal-fire a4skyhawk.org/sites/a4skyhawk.org/files/images/forrestald... www.gonavy.jp/CVW-AAf.html The deployment was immediately curtailed and the ship headed for emergency repairs and the eventual journey home to Norfolk Virginia…… while an in depth enquiry was conducted. The voyage lasted from June 6 to September 14, 1967 - not the usual up to nine months. A-4E 152023 must have been on the hangar deck and escaped direct damage. This was the only wartime posting of USS Forrestal and from then on the ship remained in the Atlantic and Mediterranean regions until decommissioned. After cleaning, in August 1967 some of the surviving Skyhawks including A-4E 152023 were transferred direct to VA-153 ‘Tail Flies’ to fly off CVA-43 USS Coral Sea as this carrier’s squadrons where incurring losses. 1967-1968 Coral Sea squadrons took part in some of the heaviest raids of the war: www.usscoralsea.net/pages/mtjas.php On January 25, 1968 A-4E 152023 suffered substantial flak damage over North Vietnam Luckily its pilot was uninjured and able to safely land the plane. It was sent for repairs and waited in Japan as an attrition replacement From November 1968 it joined VA-94 ‘Mighty Shrikes’ as part of CVW-5 tail code NF. A-4E 152023 served with VA-94 aboard CVA-31 USS Bon Homme Richard in the onslaught of the Vietnam War for two more years before going for maintenance and repair in November 1970. This A-4E Skyhawk was one of the relatively few to survive flying over dangerous North Vietnamese and South East Asian skies. Between 1971 & 1973 A-4E 152023 became one of the first batch of sixty five transferred to the then Israel Defense Force Air Force as direct US aid and attrition replacements. The aircraft would have served with more than one squadron and its tail pipe lengthened to protect against infrared guided missiles plus other necessary modifications. So in April 1971 A-4E 152023 was officially struck off charge from the US Navy to fly attack missions for Israel from its territory. Please follow these internet links for further insight: www.aeroflight.co.uk/waf/aa-mideast/israel/af/types/A-4E.htm "….. ex-US Navy A-4E delivered from February 1971 to 1973." 152023 is among the list. a4skyhawk.org/2e/israel/israel.htm 'ISRAEL' a4skyhawk.org/2e/israel/israeli-skyhawk-combat.htm 'Israeli Ayits (Vulture) in Combat' Due to losses incurred during the "Yom Kippur War", 46 more A-4E were transferred to Israel from the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps. Research place losses of Israeli Skyhawks at forty-eight. Israel is extremely secretive about defense and little information is available publicly to enable research to match US Navy serial numbers to their Israeli ones. It appears that after service with the IDFAF A-4E 152023 was one of several A-4E chosen by Israel Aerospace Industries for possible sale to Argentina, possibly its Naval air arm – then refurbished and painted in overall light gray. The sale fell through and the aircraft were then stored outdoors for eventual disposal Internet records are several years out of date as first date of record is year 2005: a4skyhawk.org/2e/israel/israel.htm So the actual fate of A-4E 152023 is a little obscure. Evidence for the above may also be gleaned by copying this hyperlink to a search engine and selecting translate: www.zonamilitar.com.ar/foros/threads/todo-sobre-el-a-4-sk... scrolling down using slider bar on right to a cryptic reference to those that may have been selected for sale to Argentina may be viewed…….. English translation appears as thus: “The A-4E Ayit of Israel who were for the Navy were 12. (According to Nuñez Padin in Naval No. 24)” BuNo. 3 150 092-A-301 3 151 056-A-302 3 151 120-A-303 3 151 164-A-304 3 151 994-A-305 3 152 019-A-306 3 152 023-A-307 3 152 030-A-308 3 152 044-A-309 3 152 050-A-310 3 152 078-A-311 3 152 097-A-312 Use of ‘Google Map’ satellite image of Ovda Airport/Air Base reveals forty aircraft hulks in lines to the south west side of the airfield area. Six possible F-4 shapes, four possible Kfir/Nesher and the rest unidentifiable, but one of which may be A-4E 152023 ………………………………………………………………….... Another ‘Flickr’ pic with A-4E 152023 included during 1969: www.flickr.com/photos/10243214@N07/3390626094/ A-4F 403 - 415 – 413 Three Douglas A-4E Skyhawks of VA-94 'Mighty Shrikes' with last four of serial on lower tail. Modex code 403 – last four of serial; 2032 = Bu No 152023 Modex code 415 – last four of serial; 2062 = Bu No 152062 Modex code 413 - last four of serial; 2037 = Bu No 152037 A 1969 color picture of A-4E 152023 with VA-94 ‘Mighty Shrikes’: a4skyhawk.org/3e/va94/va94.htm a4skyhawk.org/content/152023-va-94-nick-williams-3313 left front view of Mighty Shrikes Skyhawk BuNo 152023, NF-403, LCdr. C.B. Bot... as she taxies across the ramp. p/c is ADJ-3 C.L. Thomas NAS Barbers Point Hawaii 1969
